page.title: Liberty Displaying the Arts and Sciences

revision.text:
{{Infobox Artwork | title=Liberty Displaying the Arts and Sciences | image_file = Liberty Displaying the Arts and Sciences, or The Genius of America Encouraging the Emancipation of the Blacks, 1792.jpg | alt = Samuel Jennings (active 1789-1834). Liberty Displaying the Arts and Sciences, or The Genius of America Encouraging the Emancipation of the Blacks, 1792. Oil on canvas. 60 1/4" x 74". Library Company of Philadelphia. Gift of the artist, 1792. | artist=Samuel Jennings (artist) | year=1792 | medium=Oil-on-canvas | height_imperial={{frac|60|1|4}} | width_imperial= 74 | height_metric= 153 | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | museum=Library Company of Philadelphia }} '''''Liberty Displaying the Arts and Sciences''''' (1792) is an [[Oil painting|oil-on-canvas painting]] by [[Visual arts of the United States|American artist]] [[Samuel Jennings (artist)|Samuel Jennings]].
The [[Library Company of Philadelphia]], a private [[lending library]] founded by [[Benjamin Franklin]] in the mid-18th century, [[Commission (art)|commissioned]] Jennings (an ex-Philadelphian relocated to [[London]]) to create a work depicting "the [[Liberty (goddess)|figure of Liberty]] (with her cap and proper Insignia) displaying the arts" as a representation of [[slavery]] and a symbol of the [[Abolitionism in the United States|abolitionist]] movement.
Jennings's painting shows a [[blond]], [[White people|white]] Goddess of Liberty (with a [[Phrygian cap|liberty cap]] on a [[pike (weapon)|pike]] or [[spear]]) presenting books (the catalog of the Library Company, and two others, labeled "[[philosophy]]" and "[[agriculture]]") to three grateful, supplicant blacks (freed slaves). Surrounding the four figures, in the foreground, are various symbols of [[knowledge]] and [[learning]]: a [[Bust (sculpture)|bust]], a scroll (labeled "[[geometry]]"), papers and [[column]]s ([[architecture]]); a [[globe]] ([[geography]]), a [[lyre]] and [[sheet music]] ([[music]]), and a paper with [[Escutcheon (heraldry)|escutcheons]] on it ([[history]] and [[heraldry]]). In the background, former slaves are dancing and celebrating around a [[liberty pole]]; behind them are ships on a [[body of water]].
The work is the earliest American painting extant celebrating [[Abolitionism in the United States|emancipation]].
==References== *[[Nelson, Charmaine]]. "Hiram Powers's America: Shackles, Slaves, and the Racial Limits of Nineteenth-Century Identity." ''Canadian Review of American Studies''. Volume 34, Number 2: 2004 (p. 167-183). [http://muse.jhu.edu/cgi-bin/access.cgi?uri=/journals/canadian_review_of_american_studies/v034/34.2nelson.html&session=64254638] *Robert C. Smith. "Liberty Displaying the Arts and Sciences: A Philadelphia Allegory by Samuel Jennings." ''Winterthur Portfolio''. Volume 2: 1965.
[[Category:Abolitionism in the United States]] [[Category:1792 paintings]] [[Category:Works about American slavery]] [[Category:Liberty symbols]] [[Category:Books in art]] [[Category:Dance in art]] [[Category:Musical instruments in art]] [[Category:Ships in art]]

{{excessive detail|date=August 2016}} [[eSports|Esports]] are [[video games]] which are played in professional competitions, usually fall into a few major [[video game genre|genres]]. The majority of esports titles are [[fighting game]]s, [[first-person shooter]]s (FPS), [[real-time strategy]] (RTS), or [[multiplayer online battle arena]] games (MOBA), with the MOBA genre being the most popular in terms of participation and viewership. The following is a selection of games which currently have or had a professional scene, sorted by genre and ordered roughly chronologically.
==Fighting games== {{see also|Fighting game community}} [[Fighting game]]s were among the earliest games to be in tournaments, with the founding of what would become the [[Evolution Championship Series]] in 1999.<ref name="evoHistory">{{cite web|url=http://kotaku.com/5054856/fighting-to-play-the-history-of-the-longest-lived-fighting-game-tournament-in-the-world|title=Fighting to Play: The History of the Longest Lived Fighting Game Tournament in the World|date=2008-06-10|author=Brian Crecente| publisher=Kotaku|accessdate=10 Sep 2013}}</ref>
Competitions in the genre are generally individual competitions with both players providing input to the same machine. The genre originally focused on arcade play, but has gradually moved to console play as arcades have declined. The ''[[Street Fighter]]'' series, ''[[The King of Fighters]]'' series, ''[[Mortal Kombat]]'' series, ''[[Marvel vs. Capcom (series)|Marvel vs. Capcom]]'' series, ''[[Tekken]]'' series, ''[[Killer Instinct (series)|Killer Instinct]]'' series and ''[[Super Smash Bros. (series)|Super Smash Bros.]]'' series are amongst those fighting games played at a professional level. Important tournaments for the genre include the [[Evolution Championship Series]] and [[Capcom Cup]], [[Tougeki – Super Battle Opera]] was a major tournament for several years.<ref name="momentumMatters">{{cite web|last=Graham|first=David Philip|title=Guest Editorial – Momentum Matters: A Historical Perspective on the FGC and Esports|url=http://shoryuken.com/2011/12/12/guest-editorial-momentum-matters-a-historical-perspective-on-the-fgc-and-esports-communities-2/|publisher=Shoryuken.com|date=December 12, 2011}}</ref>
Fighting game enthusiasts generally prefer the moniker "competitive gaming", and often eschew the term "e-sports", citing cultural differences between the predominantly PC-gaming esports communities and the older arcade-gaming community.<ref>{{cite web|title=Where eSports Leagues Go Wrong With Fighters|url=http://shoryuken.com/2011/12/04/where-esports-leagues-go-wrong-with-fighters/|publisher=Shoryuken.com|date=December 4, 2011}}</ref>
Members of the fighting game community are generally especially cognizant of their cc to the old arcade-era competitions, wishing to prioritize the preservation the spirit of those competitions over simple monetization of fighting competitions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.esfiworld.com/fgc-intro-pt/|title=An introduction to the FGC Part 1: An overview|author=Jeremy Speer|date=21 Feb 2013|publisher=ESFI World|accessdate=10 Sep 2013}}</ref> <!-- Please do not add Shrek SuperSlam as a notable fighting game due to the lack of notability in the mainstream FGC. Only list fighting games that have been in the following US-based FGC run events (Combo Breaker, SoCal Regionals, NorCal Regionals, any Big E event, Final Round, The Fall Classic, CEO, EVO); remember to source information -->
===''Street Fighter''=== The ''[[Street Fighter]]'' has one of the earliest and longest running professional gaming scenes.<ref name="evoHistory" />
Professional ''Street Fighter'' players include [[Daigo Umehara]], who had two of his matches included in a 2011 [[Kotaku]] list of "The 10 Best Moments in Pro-Gaming History". His early 1998 match against American player [[Álex Vallejo|Alex Valle]] in ''[[Street Fighter Alpha 3]]'' ranked sixth and [[Evo Moment 37|his 2004 comeback]] against American player [[Justin Wong]] in ''[[Street Fighter III: Third Strike]]'' ranked first, while his 2009 grand finals match against Wong in ''[[Street Fighter IV]]'' at [[Evolution Championship Series|Evo 2009]] was listed as having "[j]ust missed the cut."<ref>{{cite web|last=Breslau|first=Rod|title=The 10 Best Moments in Pro-Gaming History|url=http://kotaku.com/5820907/the-10-best-moments-in-pro+gaming-history|publisher=Kotaku|accessdate=17 April 2012|date=July 13, 2011}}</ref>
===''Super Smash Bros.''=== {{main|Professional Super Smash Bros. competition}} [[Nintendo]]'s ''[[Super Smash Bros.]]'' series has a large [[professional Super Smash Bros. competition|competitive community]]. While every title has been featured in high-profile tournaments, ''[[Super Smash Bros. Melee]]'' and ''[[Super Smash Bros. for Wii U]]'' are the most popular for high level competition as of 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailydot.com/esports/smash-bros-wii-u-melee-esport/|title=Will Wii U's 'Smash Bros.' win over the 'Melee' crowd?|first=Imad|last=Khan|date=June 13, 2014|website=The Daily Dot|accessdate=January 27, 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150213063959/http://www.dailydot.com/esports/smash-bros-wii-u-melee-esport/|archivedate=February 13, 2015|df=}}</ref> Major League Gaming regularly sponsored ''Melee'' events from 2004 to 2007, before dropping it in favor for the 2008 sequel ''[[Super Smash Bros. Brawl]]''. According to Major League Gaming, over 400 ''Super Smash Bros. Brawl'' competitive tournaments were held in 2010 in North America.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.majorleaguegaming.com/news/super-smash-brothers-thriving-across-the-country|title=Super Smash Bros. Thriving Across the Country|publisher=[[Major League Gaming]]|author=Lish|date=2011-12-08}}</ref> Since then, ''Melee'' has again been periodically hosted at MLG events, with the latest being [[MLG 2015 World Finals]]. ''Smash Wii U'' had an online contest sponsored by ESL.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://play.eslgaming.com/new-games/wiiu/news/258468|title=Super Smash Bros. (Wii U) on ESL Play!|publisher=[[ESL Gaming]]|author=Chexx|date=July 21, 2015}}</ref> Other notable national tournaments to feature ''Smash'' games include [[Apex (tournament series)|Apex]] and [[Evolution Championship Series]] (EVO). At EVO 2016, ''Smash Wii U'' became the largest ''Smash'' tournament ever with 2,662 entrants.
===''Marvel vs. Capcom''=== ''[[Marvel vs. Capcom]]'' (MvC) is a fighting game series developed by [[Capcom]] that features characters from Capcom games and [[Marvel Comics|Marvel]] comic book characters. The series was played at the Evolution Championship Series from 2000 until 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usgamer.net/articles/a-fight-for-the-agesthe-history-of-evo|title=A Fight for the Ages: The History of EVO|publisher=US Gamer|access-date=2017-09-30}}</ref>
===''Tekken''=== [[Namco]]'s ''[[Tekken]]'' series is known as the lightning chess of fighting games, having a large player base in Asian countries. Over the years Tekken has been cited as the most technical among fighting games. Praised for its balance, strong basics, depth and one of the few fighting games to feature a real 3D design, it continues to be featured in various championships. The "Master cup" series of Japan, "Final round" series of U.S.A, "Strongstyle" series of U.S.A, "UT" championship series of Europe are a few examples of events that are, or started off as exclusive Tekken events, and still hold it as a main game. The "King of Iron Fist Tournament" is a Tekken only tournament hosted by Namco themselves. Apart from this, other shows such as "Tekken Crash", "Tekken Strike" are Tekken only shows held in South Korea on the E-sports channel "Nice Game T.V". Tekken has made it periodically into the Evo Championship series, and since 2013 has become a permanent part of the event. Although it has a lesser player-base in the west, it seems to be steadily rising. In the east it dominates the arcade scene today leaving other games of its genre miles behind.{{Citation needed|date=July 2017}}
===''Killer Instinct''=== The ''[[Killer Instinct (series)|Killer Instinct]]'' series is a combo-heavy franchise created by [[Rare (company)|Rare]] and currently maintained by [[Iron Galaxy Studios]] and [[Microsoft Studios|Microsoft]]. The franchise' most-played game is the 2013 [[Killer Instinct (2013 video game)|Killer Instinct]] reboot, with the platform of choice being [[Xbox One]]. A circuit for the game has been created called the [[Killer Instinct World Cup]],<ref>{{cite web|last1=Alexander|first1=Brandon|title=Ultra Arcade Announces Killer Instinct World Cup for 2016, $10,000 Prize Pool Guaranteed|url=http://www.ultraarcade.com/2014/12/28/ultra-arcade-announces-killer-instinct-world-cup-for-2016-10000-prize-pool-guaranteed/|website=Ultra Arcade|accessdate=2016-04-13}}</ref> with a second iteration ending in early 2017.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Jebailey|first1=Alex|title=Killer Instinct World Cup 2017 Season Announcement|url=https://www.ultra-combo.com/killer-instinct-world-cup-2017-season-announcement/|website=Ultra Combo|accessdate=2016-04-13}}</ref> Killer Instinct's best player is Jonathan "Rico Suave" Deleon, who currently holds the [[Evolution Championship Series#2015|EVO]] and Killer Instinct World Cup titles.<ref>{{cite web|title=EVO 2015: Rico Suave Wins Killer Instinct Championship with Fulgore|url=http://www.gametribute.com/4436/evo-2015-rico-suave-wins-killer-instinct-championship-with-fulgore/|website=Game Tribute|accessdate=2016-04-16}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Jurek|first1=Steven|title=Rico Suave wins Killer Instinct World Cup|url=http://www.dailydot.com/esports/rico-suave-killer-instinct-world-cup/|website=Daily Dot|accessdate=2016-04-16}}</ref>
In January 2017, Ultra Arcade enforced a ban on [[taunting]] and [[teabagging]] in [[Killer Instinct World Cup|major Killer Instinct tournaments]] which sparked controversy among the [[fighting game community]] with some stating that it is considered impossible to enforce due to certain players' playstyles.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Orland|first1=Kyle|title="Teabagging" will get you banned from a major Killer Instinct tournament|url=https://arstechnica.com/gaming/2017/01/teabagging-will-get-you-banned-from-a-major-killer-instinct-tournament/|website=[[Ars Technica]]|accessdate=2017-01-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Yin-Poole|first1=Wesley|title=Fighting game community in a flap over Killer Instinct teabagging ban|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2017-01-24-fighting-game-community-in-a-flap-over-killer-instinct-teabagging-ban|website=[[Eurogamer]]|accessdate=2017-01-24}}</ref>
==First-person shooters== [[First person shooters]] focus on simulating a [[shootout|firefight]] from a first person perspective, and may be either individual or team based. Classic games include the PC game ''[[Team Fortress 2]]'', which is featured in a few smaller leagues such as the [[ESEA League]], RGL<ref>{{cite web |title=Recharge Gaming League |url=hl.rgl.gg |website=RGL.gg |accessdate=30 November 2018}}</ref>, United Gaming Clans,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ugcleague.com/|title=UCG League|accessdate=23 Sep 2013}}</ref> and European Team Fortress 2 League.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://etf2l.org/|title=European Team Fortress 2 League|accessdate=23 Sep 2013}}</ref> ''[[Call of Duty]]''<ref name="Call of Duty">{{cite web|url=https://www.wired.com/2012/11/call-of-duty-esports/|title=Why Pro Gamers Don’t Play Call of Duty|first=RYAN |last=RIGNEY|website=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]|date=November 14, 2012|accessdate=August 22, 2015}}</ref> and ''Halo'' competitions usually play their console editions.
=== ''Doom'' === Doom is a series of multiplayer 1v1 and free-for-all deathmatch games developed by [[id Software]]. Doom is notable for establishing the arena-style deathmatch format, and also was partially responsible for the first online FPS community through DWANGO, an online gaming service officially endorsed and partially worked on by id Software. People also played Doom deathmatch online through other BBS services.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.doom2.net/history/history.html#Old_School|title=Doom2 Deathmatch History|last=BahdKo|website=www.doom2.net|access-date=2018-02-23}}</ref> [[Doom (1993 video game)|The Ultimate DOOM]] and [[Doom II|''Doom II,'']] alongside [[Heretic (video game)|Heretic]], were played in the Deathmatch '95 tournament, sponsored by [[id Software]], [[Microsoft]], and [[DWANGO]]. This tournament, perhaps the first PC esports tournament of its kind, was played through the online DWANGO service. Finalists from the US and the UK were flown to Microsoft headquarters to compete in a LAN party format event, named Judgement Day.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.thefreelibrary.com/DWANGO+to+Host+World's+Largest+Deathmatch+Tournament;+Final+Showdown...-a017453687|title=DWANGO to Host World's Largest Deathmatch Tournament; Final Showdown Played on id Raven Software's Latest Computer Game, HEXEN--Beyond Heretic, at Microsoft's "Judgment Day" Party. - Free Online Library|website=www.thefreelibrary.com|access-date=2018-02-23}}</ref> [[Dennis Fong]], best known for his victory at the [[Red Annihilation]] tournament for [[Quake (video game)|''Quake'']], won Judgement Day, marking his first entry into esports. Doom II was also played in [[Cyberathlete Professional League]] and [[QuakeCon]] tournaments.
''[[Doom 3]]'' featured a 1v1 mode which was played professionally at [[QuakeCon#2004|QuakeCon 2004]], [[QuakeCon#2005|QuakeCon 2005]], and [[Cyberathlete Professional League#2004|CPL Winter 2004]], but was ultimately replaced by ''[[Quake 4]]'' and ''[[Painkiller (video game)|Painkiller]]''.
===''Quake''=== Quake is a series 1v1 PC based games developed by [[id Software]]. In 1996, id released the original [[Quake (video game)|Quake]], and launched [[QuakeCon]]. QuakeCon is an annual convention which hosts competitions for the series, and has become the largest LAN event in North America.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pcgamer.com/gallery/quakecon-in-pictures-north-americas-biggest-lan-party-hits-dallas/|title=QuakeCon in pictures: North America's biggest LAN party|publisher=PC Gamer|author=Ian Birnbaum|date=6 Aug 2013|accessdate=15 Oct 2013}}</ref> The first offline ''Quake'' tournament, [[Red Annihilation]] took place in May 1997. The winner, [[Dennis Fong]], going under the alias "Thresh", took home the prize of ''Quake'' co-creator [[John D. Carmack]]'s own red [[Ferrari 328 GTS]] convertible.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.esreality.com/?a=post&id=1786712|title=Thresh wins Ferrari in Red Annihilation!|publisher=ES Reality|author=Jarod "Streetrunner" Reisin|date=17 Nov 2009|accessdate=2 Nov 2013}}</ref>
''[[Quake 4]]'' supported a small professional scene, with a dozen professional players signed to a few professional teams and a number of players marketing themselves through other means. Tournament play for ''Quake 4'' peaked around 2006, with the game included in tournaments such as the [[Electronic Sports World Cup]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cadred.org/News/Article/17327/|title=ESWC 2006: winz wins Quake 4|publisher=Cadred|author=Antti Paasivaara // drinn|date=2 Jul 2006|accessdate=2 Nov 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131104093152/http://www.cadred.org/News/Article/17327/|archivedate=2013-11-04|df=}}</ref> the [[World Series of Video Games]] before the league's demise,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.1up.com/news/world-series-video-games-shuts|title=World Series of Video Games Shuts Down|publisher=1Up|author=Mark Whiting|date=13 Sep 2007|accessdate=2 Nov 2013}}</ref> the [[World Cyber Games 2006]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wcg.com/renew/history/wcg2006/wcg2006_games.asp|title=WCG 2006 Games|publisher=World Cyber Games|accessdate=2 Nov 2013}}</ref> and KODE5.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.readmore.de/index.php?cont=news&id=1383&coverage=54|title=KODE5: Preisgeld und weitere Details bekannt|publisher=ReadMore.de|author=David "Craven" Abel|date=7 Mar 2006|accessdate=2 Nov 2013|language=German}}</ref> As of 2008, ''Quake 4'' has fallen out of favor in competition for the previous game in the series, ''[[Quake III Arena]]''.
''[[Quake Live]]'' was released in 2010, primarily based on ''Quake III Arena''. ''Quake Live'' was played in tournaments such as [[DreamHack]], [[QuakeCon]], and [[FaceIt]]. The popularity of the title declined after a couple years. In 2012, the last major tournament to host ''Quake'' competitions, the [[Intel Extreme Masters]], decided to drop the title.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://fnatic.com/news/8967/Fnatic-says-goodbye-to-spart1e-and-strenx.html |title=FnaticMSI says goodbye to spart1e and strenx |work=Fnatic |accessdate=2012-08-09}}</ref>
===''Counter-Strike'' series=== [[File:Finale Counter-Strike Féminin sur la scène.jpg|thumb|A Counter-Strike match in [[Electronic Sports World Cup 2007]], Paris]]
The ''[[Counter-Strike]]'' series is a series of team based first person shooters which began as a ''[[Half-Life (video game)|Half-Life]]'' [[Game mod|mod]] which was bought by [[Valve Corporation|Valve]] and released from beta in 2000. Professional competition is centered in [[North America]] and [[Europe]] in tournaments such as the [[World Cyber Games]], CEVO, [[ESEA League]], [[Intel Extreme Masters]], [[Cyberathlete Professional League]] and the [[Electronic Sports League]]. The defunct league [[Championship Gaming Series]] franchised teams with contracted players who played ''[[Counter-Strike: Source]]''.
''Counter Strike'' is consistently at competitions such as [[DreamHack]] and [[World Cyber Games]] as the 1.6 version released in 2003, despite newer versions having been released by Valve over the years.<ref name="Call of Duty" />
The most recent game in the series, Counter-Strike: Global Offensive, was released in August 2012. Although ''Counter-Strike'' did not appear in the World Cyber Games 2013,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hltv.org/news/10813-no-counter-strike-at-wcg-2013 |title=No Counter-Strike at WCG 2013 |publisher=HLTV.org | date=14 Jun 2013 | accessdate=30 Jun 2013}}</ref> the largest prizepool in the series' history has been announced for ELEAGUE, with $1.4 million USD.<ref>http://www.hltv.org/?pageid=357&eventid=2135</ref>
===''Call of Duty series''=== The ''[[Call of Duty]]'' series is a first-person shooter that has been played as an esport primarily in North America and is primarily played on [[Playstation|PlayStation]] consoles, but was formerly played on Xbox.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.foxsports.com/other/story/as-esports-grow-up-gamers-find-their-calling-103014|title=Video game sports leagues look a lot like the real thing|first=Kerouac |last=Smith|website=[[FOX Sports]]|date=October 30, 2014|accessdate=August 23, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wired.com/2012/11/call-of-duty-esports/|title=Why Pro Gamers Don’t Play Call of Duty|first=RYAN |last=RIGNEY|website=[[Wired (website)|Wired]]|date=November 14, 2012|accessdate=August 22, 2015}}</ref> It has been featured in MLG tournaments ever since ''[[Call of Duty 4: Modern Warfare]]'' was introduced to the league in 2008. Tournaments usually have a large number of unknown teams competing to play with the top pro teams. A well known example is [[OpTic Gaming]], who have earned hundreds of thousands of dollars from competing in leagues and tournaments.
===''Unreal Tournament''=== Beginning with the release of the first game in 1998, the ''[[Unreal Tournament]]'' series of first person shooters supported competitions in the early 2000s, such as the series' inclusion the World Cyber Games from 2001 through 2004.<ref name=WCG /> There are no longer major tournaments for the series, as it has been dropped from leagues such as the [[Electronic Sports League]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.esl.eu/eu/ut3/news/205465/|title=Unreal Tournament 3: Sorry, we're CLOSED|publisher=Electronic Sports League|accessdate=4 Nov 2013}}</ref>
===''Halo series''=== The ''[[Halo (series)|Halo]]'' series has been featured in the American [[Major League Gaming]] since the release of Halo: Combat Evolved for the original Xbox. The series has also been played internationally, such as the European Console League's event in July 2010 in [[Liverpool]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sk-gaming.com/content/30150-ECL_seeds_released|title=ECL seeds released|publisher=SK gaming|author=Duncan 'Thorin' Shields|date=Jul 23, 2010 <!-- 12:15 --> |accessdate=11 Sep 2013}}</ref> The Australian Cyber League hosted a Pro Circuit with tournaments in several major cities in Australia, including a January 2009 event in [[Brisbane]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://oxcgn.com/2009/01/28/halo-3-lan-brisbane-australia-cyber-leagues-09-1st/|title=Halo 3 LAN – Brisbane – Australia Cyber League's 09 1st|author=Jemimah Hawley|date=28 Jan 2009|publisher=Oxcgn|accessdate=11 Sep 2013}}</ref> Partially due to changes to the series' design, ''Halo'' competitions have gone into steep decline that started in 2010 with the release of Halo: Reach, a drastic change from what was considered traditional Halo, as seen in the original three games. The decline had continued into late 2013/2014 where Halo 4 had been introduced and was an even bigger change to the series than Halo: Reach, and as a result had no major competitive events held, other than the Halo 4 World Championships, which was put on by developer 343 Industries as an early attempt to save Halo esports. 343 Industries later released Halo: The Master Chief Collection, re-releasing all 4 original titles in 60fps, but featuring a completely remastered version of Halo 2 to use as the primary game for halo esports. Although this was a good attempt by the developer to bring back the dying community, the game suffered from many bugs and glitches that made the game unplayable, which furthermore damaged that Halo esports community. At the same time around the release of Halo: the Master Chief Collection, 343 Industries introduced the Halo Championship Series as another attempt to re-establish Halo as a competitive esports title. As Halo declined, it was dropped from Major League Gaming, to be replaced by Call of Duty as the new staple game for the league.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/insertcoin/2013/01/24/halo-out-and-cod-in-at-major-league-gaming-but-why/|title=Halo Out and COD In at Major League Gaming, but Why?|publisher=Forbes|author=Paul Tassi|date=24 Jan 2013|accessdate=30 Oct 2013}}</ref> Currently Halo 5 is the newest game in the series and has entirely built around being competitive and well suited for esports, featuring vanilla competitive settings, a wide array of competitive game modes, and an in-depth spectator mode. 343 Industries is hosting the Halo World Championships, which will be a 4v4 competition, held in part with competitive leagues MLG, ESL, and Gfinity. The prize pool is currently 2 million dollars, which is crowd funded through Halo 5's in-game "REQ Pack" purchases. The game franchise's history in esports is currently focused at the Halo Championship Series (HCS) Pro League in conjunction with the ESL esports organization, with the first season finished up in
===''Painkiller''=== ''[[Painkiller (video game)|Painkiller]]'' is a 2004 game developed by Polish game studio [[People Can Fly]] and published by [[DreamCatcher Interactive]]. At the end of 2004 ''Painkiller'' was chosen by the [[Cyberathlete Professional League]] to be their official [[2005 CPL World Tour]] game.<ref name="Painkiller-cpl2005">{{cite web | url = http://www.dreamcatchergames.com/dci/press/releases/pdf/Painkiller_cpl.pdf | title = Painkiller chosen as the unique official tournament game at 2005 CPL World Tour | work = DreamCatcher Games | accessdate = June 26, 2009 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090920014746/http://www.dreamcatchergames.com/dci/press/releases/pdf/painkiller_cpl.pdf | archivedate = September 20, 2009 | df = }}</ref> This was slightly controversial with many [[e-sports]] followers and competitors due to the fact that other games had proven themselves at least as popular online multiplayer games. As the tour had already been announced as a one-on-one [[deathmatch (gaming)|deathmatch]] format competition, ''[[Unreal Tournament 2004]]'' and ''[[Doom 3]]'' were also fan favourites for this tour. However, since ''[[Unreal Tournament 2004]]'' developer [[Epic Games]] was in the process of changing publishers from [[Atari]] to [[Midway Games]] and could not guarantee their full support throughout the year-long tour, it was not chosen. An agreement between the CPL and DreamCatcher stipulated that no other organization was allowed to use ''Painkiller'' in a gaming competition with prizes above {{USD}}2,000. without obtaining a license from the CPL. For the 2006 CPL World Tour, ''[[Quake III Arena]]'' was selected as the one-versus-one deathmatch game, replacing ''Painkiller''.<ref name="quake3-cpl2006">{{cite web|url=http://www.neowin.net/news/gamers/06/07/21/quake-3-chosen-as-cpls-2006-world-season-1vs1-game |title=Quake 3 chosen as CPL's 2006 World Season 1vs1 game |work=neowin.net |accessdate=June 26, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090915193243/http://www.neowin.net/news/gamers/06/07/21/quake-3-chosen-as-cpls-2006-world-season-1vs1-game |archivedate=September 15, 2009 |df= }}</ref>
===''Battlefield series''=== ''[[Battlefield (video game series)|Battlefield]]'' series games have been played in multiple tournaments. The PC version of the games are usually used. [[Electronic Sports League]] has sponsored ''Battlefield'' tournaments since ''[[Battlefield 2]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.esl-one.com/battlefield/|title=Battlefield|website=ESL One|accessdate=May 20, 2015}}</ref>
===''CrossFire''=== ''[[CrossFire (video game)|CrossFire]]'' is a Korean-developed shooter similar to ''Counter-Strike'' that is most popular in East Asia. CrossFire Stars is the name of the highest professional league.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.crossfirestars.com/en/cfs2015/cfs2015main.php|title=CFS 2015 – CF eSports|accessdate=November 20, 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151120202225/http://www.crossfirestars.com/en/cfs2015/cfs2015main.php|archivedate=November 20, 2015|df=}}</ref>
===''Overwatch''=== ''[[Overwatch (video game)|Overwatch]]'' has attracted attention as an esports title including teams being picked up by professional teams. Blizzard Entertainment has founded an official [[Overwatch League]] for professional, salaried players.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailydot.com/esports/overwatch-competitive-game/|title=Overwatch's future as a competitive game is bright, and this is why|first=Samuel |last=Lingle|website=[[The Daily Dot]]|date=November 17, 2015|accessdate=November 20, 2015}}</ref>
===''Team Fortress 2''=== ''[[Team Fortress 2]]'' is a class-based shooter that has been played in several online leagues, notably [[ESEA League]], [http://hl.rgl.gg/ RGL], UGC League, ETF2L, Ozfortress and Asiafortress in a 6vs6 format and a Highlander League 9vs9 format. The game has made appearances at [[DreamHack]] due to support from Razer Arena<ref>{{cite web|title=DreamHack Summer TF2 Online Qualifiers by TFCups and Razer|url=http://www.teamfortress.tv/32846/dreamhack-summer-tf2-online-qualifiers-by-tfcups-and-razer|website=TeamFortressTV|publisher=TeamFortressTV|accessdate=12 May 2016}}</ref> Team Fortress 2 has also held annual international LAN events at the [[Multiplay]] Insomnia Gaming Festival during the summer since 2012.
===''Rainbow Six: Siege''=== Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six Siege is the first esports game in the series. Official competitions of Rainbows Six Siege is Rainbow Six Pro League run by [[ESL (company)|ESL]]<ref>http://en.pro.eslgaming.com/r6/proleague/pc/</ref> and [[Ubisoft]].<ref>https://rainbow6.ubisoft.com/siege/en-gb/esports/index.aspx</ref>. Recently ESL hosted the Rainbow Six Siege [[ESL (company)|ESL]]<ref>http://en.pro.eslgaming.com/r6/proleague/pc/</ref> pro league season 8, in which G2 Esports crowned the season 8 winners.<ref>https://www.itsboomer.xyz/2018/11/rainbow-six-siege-season-8-finals.html</ref>
===''Alliance of Valiant Arms''=== ''[[Alliance of Valiant Arms]]'' (A.V.A) was a first-person shooter most popular in Asia. Developer [[Aeria Games]] sponsored a world championship, and there were also some other independent offline events held. The game has recently shut down, but a sequal (Alliance of Valiant Arms: DOG TAG) is currently in the works which will feature E-Sports.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.playava.com/comment.html|title=AVA Director comment|website=[[Play AVA]]|accessdate=November 1, 2018}}</ref>
===''Special Force II''=== ''[[Special Force II]]'' has the Special Force II Pro League in Taiwan run by the [[Taiwan eSports League|Taiwan esports League]], as well as events organized by [[Electronic Sports League]] in Europe.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://play.eslgaming.com/skill/europe|title=S.K.I.L.L. Europe |website=[[ESL Play]]|accessdate=November 20, 2015}}</ref>
==Real-time strategy== Competitions involving traditional [[real time strategy games]] generally feature individual competitors competing on [[personal computers]] over a local area network or the internet. While not nearly as popular as other RTS games during this period, the ''[[Age of Empires]]'' series was played competitively as well, and was part of the World Cyber Games from 2000-2003, and 2007-2008.<ref name=WCG>{{cite web|url=http://www.wcg.com/6th/history/wcgchallenge/wcgchallenge.asp|title=WCG History|publisher=World Cyber Games|accessdate=16 Sep 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/65dJV3ZOX?url=http://www.wcg.com/6th/history/wcgchallenge/wcgchallenge.asp|archivedate=2012-02-22|df=}}</ref>
===''StarCraft: Brood War''=== {{main|StarCraft: Brood War professional competition}} ''[[StarCraft]]'' was used at several tournaments including the [[Professional Gamers League]]. However, its expansion pack ''StarCraft: Brood War'' was far more popular than the original.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/starcraft-champs-prepare-for-world-crown-at-professional-gamers-league-tournament-77178127.html|title=StarCraft Champs Prepare for World Crown at Professional Gamers' League Tournament|website=[[PR Newswire]]|date=October 28, 1998|accessdate=May 20, 2015}}</ref>
''[[StarCraft: Brood War]]'' was foundational in the establishment of e-sports, and along with ''StarCraft II'', remains among the most popular series in competitive gaming. ''StarCraft'' competitions did especially well in [[South Korea]], which remains central to the competitive scene as a whole. Professionals in Korea achieved a status similar to professional athletes.<ref name=2012Forbes >{{cite web |title=2012: The Year of eSports|publisher=Forbes|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/insertcoin/2012/12/20/2012-the-year-of-esports/|date=20 Dec 2012|author=Paul Tassi|accessdate= 15 Aug 2013}}</ref> In the west, ''StarCraft'' enjoyed significantly less competitive popularity. ''StarCraft'' was the very first game to have been accepted into the [[World Cyber Games]] tournament, and had a tournament at their events every year until it was replaced by ''StarCraft II'' in 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sk-gaming.com/content/32458-StarCraft_2_finds_its_way_to_WCG_2011|title=StarCraft 2 finds its way to WCG 2011|author=Radoslav 'Tyrael' Kolev|date=7 Mar 2011|publisher=SK-gaming|accessdate=10 Sep 2013}}</ref> In Korea, prominent ''StarCraft'' competitions included the [[Ongamenet Starleague]], the MBCGame StarCraft League, and Proleague. Finals for these league attracted tens of thousands of fans, and became very popular on Korean cable TV.
===''Warcraft III''=== {{main|Warcraft III professional competition}} {{Further|Warcraft III World Championships}} ''[[Warcraft III]]'' has been played professionally all around the world, especially in South Korea, China, France, and Germany. Although the game never achieved the same competitive popularity of the original ''StarCraft'', the game supported a few dozen professional teams. The game lacks a singular world championship, as there have been numerous large tournaments. Events have been organized by Blizzard Entertainment, have also been televised Korean leagues, and large tournaments have been held in China. Chinese players generally have used their own clients for online competition, due to a poor connection to the outside world. Notable ''Warcraft III'' players include: [[Xiaofeng "Sky" Li]], Dae Hui "FoV" Cho, [[Jang "Moon" Jae Ho]], [[Fredrik "MaDFroG" Johansson]] and [[Manuel "Grubby" Schenkhuizen]]. In more recent times, Warcraft III competition has declined in popularity. Many professional ''Warcraft III'' players have since moved to ''[[Starcraft II]]'', including Grubby and Moon. Despite this, ''Warcraft III'' continues to be played competitively, still appearing in events such as [[WCG 2013]].
===''StarCraft II''=== [[File:2011 blizzard cup grand final.JPG|thumb|The 2011 [[GOMTV Global Starcraft II League|GSL]] championship at [[Blizzcon]].]] After its release in 2010, ''[[StarCraft II]]'' competitions gradually replaced the prior ''Brood War'' competitions. For example, ''StarCraft II'' has replaced the original game in the WCG, and the initially ''Brood War''-focused Proleague mixed ''StarCraft II'' into their competitions, before finally phasing out ''Brood War'' entirely. Initially, disagreements between Blizzard and Kespa prevented many players in Korea from moving to ''StarCraft II'', but conditions improved, and were ultimately resolved by 2012.
Many leagues and e-sports organizations in Korea and across the world host ''StarCraft II'' tournaments, including the [[Team Liquid#Team Liquid Starleague|Team Liquid StarLeague]], [[Major League Gaming]], [[North American Star League]], [[DreamHack]], the [[Intel Extreme Masters]] and the [[GOMTV Global Starcraft II League]].
In 2012, Blizzard Entertainment created the ''StarCraft II'' World Championship Series. In the tournament's [[2012 StarCraft II World Championship Series|initial 2012 season]], Korean player PartinG beat Creator to win the $100,000 grand prize.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://us.battle.net/bwc/en/tournaments/sc2/brackets |title=2012 Shanghai China WCS bracket |website=StarCraft II World Championship Series |publisher=Blizzard |accessdate=10 November 2013}}</ref> As of 2013, the WCS system divides players into three leagues: WCS Korea, WCS Europe, and WCS North America. Players earn points based on their performance in many different tournaments, including the ones mentioned above, and the 16 players with the most points advance to world championship at [[BlizzCon]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://wcs.battle.net/sc2/en/about |title=About StarCraft II World Championship Series |website=StarCraft II World Championship Series |publisher=Blizzard |accessdate=16 October 2013}}</ref> In the 2013 grand finals, sOs beat the crowd favorite [[Jaedong]] 4-1, winning the $100,000 grand prize.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://wcs.battle.net/sc2/en/articles/long-live-the-king-sos-is-your-wcs-champion |title=Long Live the King — sOs Is Your WCS Champion |website=StarCraft II World Championship Series |publisher=Blizzard |accessdate=10 November 2013}}</ref> The 2nd-place finish for Jaedong awarded him $45,000, making his total prizepool earnings $489,384.83, the highest of any esports player at that time.
==Sports games==
===''FIFA series''=== [[File:ESBL Match.JPG|thumb|[[World League eSport Bundesliga]] Kick-Off Event]] ''[[FIFA Football]]'' is a generally individual competition available on consoles as well as PCs. FIFA has been an official game of the [[World Cyber Games]] since its first tournament in 2001.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wcg.com/renew/wcg2013/officialgames_pc.asp?gID=fifa14 | title=Official Games:Fifa 14|publisher=World Cyber Games}}</ref> In 2003, a FIFA tournament was also held at the first event of [[Cyberathlete Professional League|CPL]] Europe.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sk-gaming.com/content/2429-Intel_CPL_Cannes_opens_registration|title=Intel CPL Cannes opens registration|author=Robert 'JFK' Lacroix|publisher=SK Gaming|date=Feb 5, 2003 <!-- 20:57 --> |accessdate=11 Sep 2013}}</ref> [[Germany]] has the biggest ''FIFA Football'' community, hosting leagues such as the [[Electronic Sports League]] and the [[World League eSport Bundesliga]] (which was aired on the national TV-broadcaster ''Deutsches Sportfernsehen'' before the league's cessation). There are also leagues in South Korea like the [[Ongamenet]] FifaLeague that are televised.{{citation needed|date=September 2013}} The ESL continues to host FIFA competitions into 2013,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.onlinewelten.com/games/fifa-14/news/esl-series-ps3-version-kicks-kehrt-deutsche-esport-oberhaus-zurueck-123080/|title=ESL Pro Series: PS3-Version des Kicks kehrt ins deutsche eSport-Oberhaus zurück|author=Dennis 'Leschni' Leschnikowski|date=2013-09-10|publisher=OnlineWelten.com|language=German|accessdate=12 Sep 2013}}</ref> as does the ESWC.<ref name=ESWC2013>{{cite web|url=http://www.eswc.com/en/info/3-games-confirmed|title=Dota2, FIFA and Trackmania confirmed|publisher=ESWC|date=9 May 2013|accessdate=30 Oct 2013}}</ref>
Furthermore, the [[FIFA Interactive World Cup]] (FIWC) is the world's largest video game tournament and with that the biggest FIFA tournament there is. The virtual football world championship is organised annually by [[FIFA]] and its presenting partner [[EA Sports]]. The inaugural FIWC took place in Zurich in 2004 and since then enabled millions of football fans from all around the world to fight for the world champion title. The tournament is played on the latest console generations of [[Xbox]] and [[PlayStation]].
===''Madden''=== The ''[[Madden NFL]]'' series of [[American football]] games has been used as esports. Game developer [[Electronic Arts]] sponsored a $1 million ''Madden NFL 17'' Championship Series.<ref>http://www.latimes.com/business/technology/la-fi-tn-electronic-arts-esports-20160610-snap-story.html</ref> The television series ''[[Madden Nation]]'' was an American reality television show, created as a joint effort between EA SPORTS and ESPN Original Entertainment and focused on the competitive scene of ''Madden''.
===''NBA 2K''=== In February 2017, the [[National Basketball Association]], in conjunction with [[Take-Two Interactive]], announced the creation of an esports league centering on the ''[[NBA 2K]]'' franchise. Known as the ''NBA 2K eLeague'', it is set to commence competition in 2018.<ref>Makuch, Eddie (February 9, 2017). [http://www.gamespot.com/articles/nba-launching-its-own-pro-gaming-league-with-take-/1100-6447695/ "NBA Launching Its Own Pro Gaming League With Take-Two"]. ''[[GameSpot]]''. Retrieved February 11, 2017.</ref><ref>Sarkar, Samit (February 9, 2017). [http://www.polygon.com/2017/2/9/14554226/nba-2k-esports-eleague-2018 "NBA 2K maker teaming up with NBA for esports league"]. ''[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]''. Retrieved February 11, 2017.</ref><ref>Wolf, Jacob (May 4, 2017). [http://www.espn.com/esports/story/_/id/19305330/nba-announces-17-teams-participate-nba-2k-esports-league "NBA announces 17 teams will participate in NBA 2K League"]. ''[[ESPN]]''. Retrieved May 10, 2017.</ref>
===''Pro Evolution Soccer''=== [[PES League]] is the official competition series of ''[[Pro Evolution Soccer]]'' run by [[Konami]]. In 2016 and 2017, the PES League final competition was held together with [[UEFA Champions League]] finals.
===''Rocket League''=== ''[[Rocket League]]'' competitions have been run by [[Twitch.tv]], [[Psyonix Studios]], [[ESL (company)|ESL]] and [[Major League Gaming]] as well as other independent tournaments. The $100,000 2v2 Rocket League tournament will kick off in July through the online competitive gaming platform, FaceIt, and move onto regional finals through select NBC Sports regional networks including New England, the Bay Area, and other non-NBC regional networks around the world — a first for Rocket League. The grand finals in August will be broadcast on NBC Sports Network in the U.S. and on Syfy in a handful of other countries. <ref>http://www.redbull.com/us/en/esports/stories/1331810143658/rocket-league-s-roadmap-to-esports-success</ref><ref>http://mashable.com/2017/06/21/rocket-league-nbc-television/#P8EcdXujaOqN</ref>
===Real Subspace Hockey League=== [[RSHL]] competitions have been running since 1998,<ref>https://web.archive.org/web/20030628175533/http://www.rshl.org/archive/arc-0898.shtml</ref> making this online hockey league one of the oldest sport based esports on the net. Currently RSHL Season 25 is being played using a Waiver-based team system. Recent years competitions have been aired on both [[YouTube]] and [[Twitch.tv]].<ref>https://www.twitch.tv/subspacehz</ref> Although most teams and seasons have been strictly amateur, various paid players and performance based pay teams have competed over the years to try and win the coveted "Blackie" cup. Most league players have 1000s of hours of experience giving the game a very competitive atmosphere.
==Racing==
===''iRacing''=== [[NASCAR]] hosts an affiliated annual video game competition since 2010 known as the [[NASCAR iRacing.com World Championship Series]], which had a grand prize of $10,500 USD in 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamingupdate.com/news/2932/iRacing-com-NASCAR-and-Grand-Prix-Champions-Crowned|title=iRacing.com NASCAR and Grand Prix Champions Crowned|author=CM Boots-Faubert|date=26 Oct 2011|publisher=GamingUpdate|accessdate=1 Aug 2013}}</ref>
===''Project CARS''=== ''[[Project CARS]]'' has become an official esport with the [[Electronic Sports League]] and has become a success.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.projectcarsgame.com/home/project-cars-becomes-an-official-esport-with-esl|title=Project CARS becomes an official eSport with ESL|author=unknown|date=8 Sep 2015|publisher=Project CARS}}</ref>
===''TrackMania''=== ''[[TrackMania]]'' is a racing game franchise developed by [[Nadeo]], and has been an esport since 2006. The majority of the competition on this game are played in TrackMania 2: Stadium, and many tournaments have taken place since then. Until 2015, TrackMania 2: Stadium even had a world cup which took place every year, and the game still has important tournaments with price pools sometimes exceeding US$10,000.
==Multiplayer online battle arena== [[Multiplayer online battle arena]] (MOBA) games are historically a spin-off of real-time strategy games, but are different enough that they are now generally considered a separate genre. While traditional RTS games feature many units controlled by a single player, MOBAs are typically team focused, the model being five players on a team, each controlling a single "hero" unit. MOBAs are generally played on personal computers.
===''Dota 2''===
[[File:The International 2014.jpg|250px|thumb|left|A match during the main event of [[The International 2014]] at the [[KeyArena]] in Seattle]] The ''Dota'' franchise began as a fan-made ''[[Warcraft III: Reign of Chaos]]'' [[mod (video gaming)|mod]] named ''[[Defense of the Ancients]]'' (''DotA''), released in 2003. The popularity of the original mod, both in casual and competitive play, encouraged [[Valve Corporation]] to create a stand-alone sequel, ''[[Dota 2]]''. Together, the two games are amongst the most popular electronic sports games played professionally. These titles have been featured at major international tournaments, including [[DreamHack]],<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.sk-gaming.com/content/35427-DreamHack_Winter_to_feature_Dota_2 | title = DreamHack Winter to feature Dota 2 | date = 2011-11-02 | last = Horton | first = Samuel | publisher = SK Gaming}}</ref> as well as the [[World Cyber Games]] and [[Electronic Sports World Cup|ESWC]] events.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eswc.com/additional-rts-announcement |title=Electronic Sports World Cup - ESWC 2011 |publisher=Eswc.com |date= |accessdate=2012-05-25}}</ref> Valve hosted ''Dota 2'''s public debut in 2011 at [[The International 2011|The International]], which featured a USD$1 million grand prize.<ref>{{cite web | author= Jim Reilly | url = http://pc.ign.com/articles/118/1185390p1.html | title = Valve Goes Big with Dota 2 Tournament | date = 1 Aug 2011 | publisher = IGN| accessdate= 1 Jul 2013 }}</ref> In 2012, Valve hosted [[The International 2012]], which also had a million dollar grand prize.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/gregvoakes/2012/09/04/dota-2-the-international-2-and-the-future-of-esports/|title=Dota 2: 'The International 2', And The Future Of eSports|publisher=Forbes|author=Greg Voakes|date=4 Sep 2012|accessdate=30 Oct 2013}}</ref> The following two internationals set records for having the largest esports prize pool at the time.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/valves-dota-2-international-championship-begins/1100-6412498/|title=Valve's Dota 2 International Championship begins|publisher=GameSpot|author=Rod Breslau|date=3 Aug 2013|accessdate=30 Oct 2013}}</ref> [[The International 2015]] boasted a prize pool that totalled over $18 million USD,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.pcgamer.com/the-international-2015-prize-distribution-announced/|title=The International 2015 prize distribution announced|last=Savage|first=Phil|date=July 21, 2015|website=PC Gamer|publisher=|access-date=July 21, 2015}}</ref> making it the largest esports prize pool for a single tournament until it got surpassed by The International 2016, which boasted a prize pool that totalled over $20 million USD.
Early in the development of ''Dota 2'', Valve was legally opposed by Riot Games and Blizzard Entertainment, both of which voiced their opinions that the ''DotA'' name should have remained a community asset. In August 2010, Riot filed an opposing trademark for "DotA", in order to "protect the work that dozens of authors have done to create the game".<ref>{{cite web |last=Augustine |first=Josh |url=http://www.pcgamer.com/2010/08/17/riot-games-dev-counter-files-dota-trademark/ |title=Riot Games' dev counter-files "DotA" trademark |date=August 17, 2010 |publisher=[[PC Gamer]] |archivedate=February 3, 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130203103306/http://www.pcgamer.com/2010/08/17/riot-games-dev-counter-files-dota-trademark/ }}</ref> Valve subsequently won the case, but was opposed by Blizzard, who filed a trademark with similar reasoning.<ref>{{cite web |last=Plunkett |first=Luke |url=http://kotaku.com/5883938/blizzard-and-valve-go-to-war-over-dota-name |title=Blizzard and Valve go to War Over DOTA Name |date=February 10, 2012 |publisher=Kotaku |archivedate=June 4, 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120604075718/http://kotaku.com/5883938/blizzard-and-valve-go-to-war-over-dota-name}}</ref> In May 2012, Blizzard and Valve announced that the dispute had been settled, with Valve retaining the commercial franchising rights to the term ''"Dota"'', while non-commercial usage of the name could still be used.<ref>{{cite web |last=Reilly |first=Jim |url=http://www.gameinformer.com/b/news/archive/2012/05/11/valve-blizzard-reach-dota-trademark-agreement.aspx |title=Valve, Blizzard Reach DOTA Trademark Agreement |date=May 11, 2012 |publisher=[[Game Informer]] |archivedate=July 24, 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120724090129/http://www.gameinformer.com/b/news/archive/2012/05/11/valve-blizzard-reach-dota-trademark-agreement.aspx }}</ref> By July 2016, ''Dota 2'' tournaments had awarded roughly $65 million in prize money altogether, with 12 players winning over $1 million each.
===''League of Legends''=== ''[[League of Legends]]'' (''LoL'') is a multiplayer online battle arena video game developed and published by [[Riot Games]], primarily inspired by ''Defense of the Ancients''. It was released on October 27, 2009. In an early ''LoL'' tournament, the game was featured as a promotional title in the [[2010 World Cyber Games]] in Los Angeles. The victors were the Counter Logic Gaming team from North America, winning a $7,000 prize. ''LoL'' was added to the [[Intel Extreme Masters]] lineup for the 2011 Electronic Sports League season.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sk-gaming.com/content/33716-IEM_Season_VI_announced_LoL_added |title=IEM Season VI announced, LoL added |publisher=SK Gaming |date=27 Jun 2011 |accessdate=1 Jul 2013}}</ref> [[League of Legends World Championships#The Season 1 World Championships|The Season 1 World Championships]] were held at [[DreamHack]] Summer 2011 in Sweden.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dreamhack.se/DHS11/2011/04/08/lol-season-one-championship-at-dhs/|title=LOL Season One Championship at DHS|publisher=DreamHack|author=staff|accessdate=30 Oct 2013}}</ref> The European team Fnatic defeated teams from Europe and the USA to win US$50,000 of the tournament's US$100,000 prize pool.<ref>{{cite web|author=hxd Harry Wiggett |url=http://fnatic.com/news/8954/FnaticMSI-LoL-jet-off-to-LA.html |title=FnaticMSI.LoL jet off to LA! |publisher=FNATIC.com |date=2011-07-13 |accessdate=2012-05-25}}</ref> According to Riot, the final match drew 210,000 concurrent viewers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.joystiq.com/2011/06/22/league-of-legends-championship-draws-nearly-1-7-million-viewers/#continued|title=League of Legends championship draws nearly 1.7 million viewers|publisher=Joystiq|author=Richard Mitchell|date=Jun 22, 2011 <!-- 2:15PM --> |accessdate=11 Sep 2013}}</ref>
Riot announced a prize pool of US $5 million to be paid out over Season 2, allocated to tournaments featuring League of Legends.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sk-gaming.com/content/34394-Season_2_will_have_a_5_Million_prize_fund|title=Season 2 will have a $5 Million prize fund!|author=Scott 'aBhorsen' Parkin|date=15 Aug 2011|accessdate=11 Sep 2013|publisher=SK gaming}}</ref> the [[Season 2 World Championship]] featured a prize pool of $2 million USD. Taipei Assassins of [[Taiwan]] defeated [[Azubu Frost]] of [[South Korea]] in the grand finals, winning the $1 million grand prize. During the quarterfinal match against Team Solomid, Azubu Frost player Woong looked at the spectator minimap, resulting in a fine that reduced their winnings by US$30,000.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://na.leagueoflegends.com/board/showthread.php?t=2663221 |title=World Playoffs - Rule Violations |publisher=leageuoflegends.com |date=2012-12-12 |accessdate=2012-11-16}}</ref> The League of Legends Season 2 World Finals match drew a peak of 1.1 million concurrent viewers, who observed the matches from Internet streams, Korean television, and Chinese television.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/news/league-of-legends-season-2-championships-most-watched-esports-event-of-all-time-6398663 |title=League of Legends Season 2 Championships most watched eSports event of all time |publisher=gamespot.com |date=2012-10-22| accessdate=2012-11-21}}</ref>
In season 3, the total prize pool was US $8 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.polygon.com/2013/7/11/4514840/league-of-legends-season-3-world-championship-final-staples-center|title=League of Legends Season 3 final heads to Staples Center|publisher=Polygon|author=Samit Sarkar|date=11 Jul 2013|accessdate=30 Oct 2013}}</ref> [[League of Legends World Championships#The Season 3 World Championships|The 2013 Season 3 Championships]] was held in Los Angeles, featuring a prize pool is $2 million with $1 million for first place. The team [[SK Telecom T1|SKT T1]] won the final, which took place at the [[Staples Centre]] on October 4.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/league-of-legends-season-3-world-championships-to-be-held-at-staples-center/1100-6411299/|title= League of Legends Season 3 World Championships to be held at Staples Center|publisher=GameSpot|author=staff|date=11 Jul 2013|accessdate=23 Oct 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.esfiworld.com/skt-t1-celebrate-their-season-3-championship-claim-summoners-cup/|title=SKT T1 celebrate their Season 3 championship, claim Summoner's Cup|publisher=ESFI World|author=staff|date=5 Oct 2013|accessdate=23 Oct 2013}}</ref> The event drew 1.4 million concurrent viewers during the final series.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sfasyou.com/2013/10/07/league-of-legends-season-3-world-championship-draws-over-1-4-million-viewers/|title=League of Legends Season 3 World Championship draws over 1.4 Million viewers|publisher=SFAS you|author=Jorge Lopez|date=7 Oct 2013|accessdate=6 Nov 2013}}</ref>
===''Heroes of the Storm''=== ''[[Heroes of the Storm]]'', developed by Blizzard, has been a popular MOBA for esports competitions. The collegiate finals of HotS was broadcast on [[ESPN2]] in a special program called ''Heroes of the Dorm''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pcgamer.com/heroes-of-the-dorm-finals-were-a-success-story-for-esports/|title=Heroes of the Dorm finals were a success story for esports|website=[[PCGamer]]|first=Tom|last=Marks|date=April 27, 2015|accessdate=May 4, 2015}}</ref> Starting in 2017 Blizzard has organised the Heroes Global Championship (HGC), the league is a year long competition consisting of four phases. Eight teams from the four regions (Europe, North America, South Korea and China) compete for spots in global tournemants that cap each phase of the league. The grand finale is held Blizzcon.
===''Heroes of Newerth''=== ''Heroes of Newerth'' has been at [[DreamHack]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dreamhack.se/dhs15/2015/03/03/heroes-of-newerth-is-back-at-dreamhack/|title=Heroes Of Newerth is back at DreamHack « Dreamhack DreamHack Summer 2015|website=[[DreamHack]]|accessdate=August 22, 2015}}</ref>
===''Smite''=== ''[[Smite (video game)|Smite]]'' is a third-person MOBA developed and published by [[Hi-Rez Studios]]. Prior to release, ''Smite'' was kept in an extended beta that resulted in over 74 million hours of playtime and the realization of a robust competitive community.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hirezstudios.com/smite/latest-news/view/smite-blog/2014/03/25/hi-rez-studios-releases-smite-in-north-america-and-europe |title=Hi-Rez Studios releases Smite in North America and Europe |publisher=Hi-Rez Studios |date=25 Mar 2014 |accessdate=20 Jun 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140613115428/http://www.hirezstudios.com/smite/latest-news/view/smite-blog/2014/03/25/hi-rez-studios-releases-smite-in-north-america-and-europe |archivedate=2014-06-13 |df= }}</ref> Throughout the beta, Hi-Rez hosted a series of LAN and online events with cash prize pools.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hirezstudios.com/esports/blog-post/esports/2013/10/14/smite-tournament-series-week-24-recap |title=Smite Tournament Series: Week 24 Recap |publisher=Hi-Rez Studios |date=14 Oct 2013 |accessdate=20 Jun 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714222932/http://www.hirezstudios.com/esports/blog-post/esports/2013/10/14/smite-tournament-series-week-24-recap |archivedate=2014-07-14 |df= }}</ref> ''Smite'' was officially released in North America and western Europe on March 25, 2014.
The weekend following its release, Hi-Rez hosted a Smite Launch Tournament in Atlanta where the eight best teams from Europe and North America played for a prize pool of over $200,000 USD, half of which was raised by the community from sales of a character skin.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hirezstudios.com/smite/nav/launch-info/launch-details |title=Atlanta 2014 SMITE Launch Tournament |publisher=Hi-Rez Studios |date=1 Mar 2014 |accessdate=20 Jun 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140621055722/http://www.hirezstudios.com/smite/nav/launch-info/launch-details |archivedate=2014-06-21 |df= }}</ref> [[Team Solo Mid]] from Europe won first place, with [[Team Dignitas]] from North America taking second place. Viewers at home could make their own predictions for a chance to win various prizes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hirezstudios.com/smite/latest-news/view/smite-blog/2014/03/18/release-the-bracken! |title=Release The Bracken! Promotion |publisher=Hi-Rez Studios |date=18 Mar 2014 |accessdate=20 Jun 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140702163023/http://www.hirezstudios.com/smite/latest-news/view/smite-blog/2014/03/18/release-the-bracken%21 |archivedate=2014-07-02 |df= }}</ref> According to Hi-Rez, the event drew more than 400,000 unique viewers worldwide.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hirezstudios.com/smite/latest-news/view/esports/2014/04/02/smite-launch-tournament-results-and-recap |title=SMITE Launch Tournament Results and Recap |publisher=Hi-Rez Studios |date=2 Apr 2014 |accessdate=20 Jun 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140626114625/http://www.hirezstudios.com/smite/latest-news/view/esports/2014/04/02/smite-launch-tournament-results-and-recap |archivedate=2014-06-26 |df= }}</ref> After the event, Hi-Rez added a custom-branded skin in honor of Team Solo Mid's victory.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pxgieYthgMg |title=New Apollo Skin: Team SoloMid |publisher=Hi-Rez Studios |date=25 May 2014 |accessdate=20 Jun 2014}}</ref>
In May 2014, Hi-Rez announced the Smite World Championship Series (SWC). The SWC began with three months of regional qualifiers, which culminated into two separate $50,000 USD regional LAN events for Europe and North America.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hirezstudios.com/esports/blog-post/esports/2014/05/01/smite-world-championship-series |title=SMITE: World Championship Series |publisher=Hi-Rez Studios |date=1 May 2014 |accessdate=20 Jun 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140605192455/http://www.hirezstudios.com/esports/blog-post/esports/2014/05/01/smite-world-championship-series |archivedate=5 June 2014 |df= }}</ref> The SWC took place on January 9–11, 2015 at the Cobb Energy Performing Arts Centre in Atlanta, and featured a prize pool of $2,612,260 USD, raised from the community through the sale of digital cosmetics and special edition items. The World Championship featured teams from North America, Europe, China, Brazil, and Latin America.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hirezstudios.com/smite/promo/archived/smite-world-championship-2015 |title=The SMITE World Championship Overview |publisher=Hi-Rez Studios |accessdate=4 Jun 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150602212701/http://www.hirezstudios.com/smite/promo/archived/smite-world-championship-2015 |archivedate=2015-06-02 |df= }}</ref> After several matches, the North American team COGnitive Prime (Now Cloud9 G2A) took 1st place earning $1,306,130 USD, with Titan, a European team who began their run to the SMITE World Championship in the open amateur scene, coming in second place.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2015/01/12/smite-world-championship-winners/ |title= COGnitive Prime win SWC |publisher= Rock Paper Shotgun |date= January 12, 2015 |accessdate= 4 Jun 2015}}</ref> Afterwards, much like the Smite Launch Tournament, a branded cosmetic skin was released to honor COGnitive Prime and an invitational competition scheduled in their name.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hirezstudios.com/smite/latest-news/view/smite-blog/2015/03/20/cog-scylla-invitational |title= COG Scylla Invitational|publisher= Hi-Rez Studios |date= Mar 20, 2015 |accessdate= 4 Jun 2015}}</ref>
===''Vainglory''=== [[Mobile video game]] ''[[Vainglory (video game)|Vainglory]]'' has attracted some interest as an esports game, including the sponsorship of a team by [[SK Gaming]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.redbull.com/en/esports/stories/1331749513049/what-the-future-holds-for-team-dignitas|title=SK Gaming enter mobile esports by acquiring top Vainglory franchise|first=Saira |last=Mueller|website=[[The Daily Dot]]|date=November 18, 2015|accessdate=November 20, 2015}}</ref> It boasted the largest prize money awarded for a mobile game with $350,000 from tournaments around the world in Fall 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.superevilmegacorp.com/blog/twitch-and-super-evil-megacorp-partner-for-expanded-vainglory-esports-program|title=Twitch and Super Evil Megacorp Partner for Expanded Vainglory Esports Program — Super Evil Megacorp|first=|last=|website=|date=March 31, 2016|accessdate=}}</ref>
==Others==
=== ''EndGods'' === EndGods is an Online Real-Time Action Strategy game for iOS, Android and PC. Players get to select a lineup of 8 heroes with unique skills and attributes to deploy onto a multi-path battleground. The objective is to outplay the opponent's heroes and destroy their base at the end of each path. Strategy, execution and timing are key, players will be challenged by cooldowns and mana management.
Launching out of Singapore, EndGods held the first League of Gods tournament in November 2015 with a prize pool of SGD$30,000. The second installment of the League of Gods tournament series concluded in May 2016, with a total prize pool of SGD$100,000. The third tournament in the series is planned for early 2017 and will have a total prize pool of SGD$250,000.
==='' Gears of War''=== ''[[Gears of War]]'' is a [[third-person shooter]] series developed by [[The Coalition (company)|The Coalition]]. It is usually played during [[ESL (eSports)|ESL]] and [[Major League Gaming]] events. In 2016, [[Xbox]] and the Coalition announced the a Pro Circuit for ''[[Gears of War 4]]'', with the prize pool being one million USD.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.xbox.com/2016/08/01/gears-esports-pro-circuit-announcement/|title=Announcing the Gears eSports Pro Circuit for Gears of War 4 with $1,000,000 Prize Pool|first=Jack|last=Felling|website=xbox | date=August 1, 2016}}</ref>
===''War Thunder''=== ''[[War Thunder]]'' (WT) is a cross-platform MMO combat game for PC, PS4, Mac and Linux, dedicated to World War II military aviation, armoured vehicles, and fleets developed by [[Gaijin Entertainment]] that was first released in 2012. War Thunder held the first season of its Thunder League tournament in Late 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pcgamesn.com/war-thunder/war-thunder-s-esports-league-reaches-playoffs-with-over-40000-up-for-grabs|title=War Thunder eSports League reaches playoffs with over $40,000 up for grabs|first=Joe|last=Donnelly|website=pcgamesn | date=January 20, 2016}}</ref> The tournament prize fund was directly funded by the players of game through the purchase of special in game goods, with the final prize pool reaching a sum of $57,425 distributed between 6 teams.
===''World of Tanks''=== ''[[World of Tanks]]'' (WoT) is an MMO tank game for PC and Xbox One developed by [[Wargaming (company)|Wargaming]] that was first released in 2010. Since 2012, the company has been heavily invested in the WoT esports scene.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.redbull.com/en/esports/stories/1331717624679/world-of-tanks-grand-finals-behind-the-scenes|title=World of Tanks Grand Finals: Behind the scenes|first=Ben|last=Sillis|website=[[Red Bull]] Esports|date=April 21, 2015}}</ref> There is annual world championship with qualifier tournaments held across the world. The [[Electronic Sports League]] also sponsors some WoT tournaments.
===''World of Warcraft''=== Blizzard's [[Massively multiplayer online|MMO]] ''[[World of Warcraft]]'' added PvP features to the game after its release, and was received enthusiastically as an eSport.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sk-gaming.com/content/20118-WoW_is_an_esport|title=WoW is an esport|publisher=SK Gaming|author=Michael 'Zechs' Radford|date=25 Nov 2008|accessdate=30 Oct 2013}}</ref> The game was generally phased out of MLG between 2010 and 2011,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sk-gaming.com/content/30957-No_more_WoW_at_MLG|title=No more WoW at MLG?|publisher=SK Gaming|author='hydrolis'|date=18 Oct 2010|accessdate=30 Oct 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.complexitygaming.com/news/2396/|title=MLG Season Details Announced|publisher=Complexity Gaming|author=coL_aMies|date=3 Feb 2011|accessdate=30 Oct 2013}}</ref> but Blizzard continues to hold the World of Warcraft Arena Global Invitational annually. The prize pool for the 2013 World of Warcraft Arena Global Invitational totaled over $180,000<ref>{{cite web|url=http://us.battle.net/wow/en/blog/11289177/|title=BlizzCon® World of Warcraft Arena Global Invitational|publisher=Blizzard Entertainment|date=2013-08-21}}</ref> and that of the 2014 World of Warcraft Arena Invitational World Championship totaled $250,000.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://us.battle.net/wow/en/blog/14934601/world-of-warcraft-arena-invitational-world-championship-learn-the-score-7-23-2014|title=World of Warcraft Arena Invitational World Championship: Learn the Score|publisher=Blizzard Entertainment|date=2014-07-23}}</ref>
===''Hearthstone''=== {{main|Professional Hearthstone play}} ''[[Hearthstone (video game)|Hearthstone]]'' is a digital [[collectible card game]] from [[Blizzard Entertainment]].<ref name="WoW Head">{{cite web|title=Hearthstone: Heroes of Warcraft Announced|url=http://www.wowhead.com/news=211571/hearthstone-heroes-of-warcraft-announced|publisher=WoW Head|accessdate=22 March 2013}}</ref><ref name=IGN>{{cite web|title=Blizzard Reveals Hearthstone: Heroes of Warcraft|url=http://uk.ign.com/articles/2013/03/22/blizzard-reveals-hearthstone-heroes-of-warcraft|publisher=IGN|accessdate=22 March 2013}}</ref> It has gained popularity as an eSport with [[Major League Gaming|MLG]] and [[BlizzCon]] hosting tournaments.<ref name="MLG/ManaGrind">{{cite web|title=MLG/ManaGrind NA & EU Open 4 HS Tournament!|url=http://us.battle.net/hearthstone/en/forum/topic/10490559677|accessdate=11 November 2013}}</ref><ref name="Blizzcon Innkeepers Invitational">{{cite web|title=Innkeeper's Invitational Reminder|url=http://us.battle.net/hearthstone/en/blog/11514704/innkeeper%E2%80%99s-invitational-reminder-11-9-2013|accessdate=11 November 2013}}</ref>
===''Pokémon''=== The ''[[Pokémon]]'' series of strategy video games are played competitively.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.redbull.com/uk/en/esports/stories/1331653534794/pokemon-video-game-championship|title=Pokémon: The friendly eSport|date=May 23, 2014|first=Tom |last=East|website=[[Red Bull]] Esports|accessdate=August 22, 2015}}</ref> A [[The Pokémon Company|Pokémon Company]]-sponsored [[Pokémon World Championships|world championship]] organized by their [[Play! Pokémon]] division has been held annually for several years.
=== ''Puyo Puyo'' === ''[[Puyo Puyo]]'' was approved as an esports game by the Japanese esports Union in March 2018. The first esports tournament for the game was held during Sega Fest 2018 from April 14 to April 15 of the same year.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.siliconera.com/2018/03/12/puyo-puyo-series-gets-recognized-esports-game-japan/|title=Puyo Puyo Series Gets Recognized As An eSports Game In Japan - Siliconera|date=2018-03-12|work=Siliconera|access-date=2018-06-01|language=en-US}}</ref>
===''Tetris''=== There is a [[Classic Tetris World Championship]] for the puzzle game ''[[Tetris]]''.
===''Splatoon''=== [[Splatoon]] and [[Splatoon 2]] are both [[Third-person shooter|third person shooters]] developed by [[Nintendo]]. They have both held several large tournaments, including the Inkling Open and the [[Electronic Entertainment Expo]] World Championship 2018, as well as local tournaments.
==See also== * [[List of video game genres]] * [[Video games notable for speedrunning]] * [[Mind sport]]

'''MUNFLA''' (Memorial University of Newfoundland Folklore and Language Archive) is the largest sound recording [[folklore]] archive in Canada. It is hosted at [[Memorial University of Newfoundland]], located in the G.A. Hickman Building at the [[St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador|St. John’s]] campus in [[Newfoundland and Labrador|Newfoundland]], Canada. It is a member of the [http://www.cdncouncilarchives.ca/intro.html Canadian Council of Archives] and the [https://web.archive.org/web/20100214050438/http://www.anla.nf.ca/index.php Association of Newfoundland and Labrador Archives]. MUNFLA was founded in 1968 by folklorist Herbert Halpert, head of the Folklore Department, as a joint-venture by the Folklore and English departments at [[Memorial University]]. The archive was created as a repository for recordings and material culture of [[Newfoundland and Labrador]] folk culture.
== Collection ==
The archive contains a variety of items including oral histories, [[songs]], [[poetry]], [[childlore]], folk narratives, personal experience narratives, folk beliefs as well as student research papers and graduate theses and dissertations from the Department of Folklore.
==External links==
MUNFLA operates an online [https://www.mun.ca/folklore/munfla/fonds.php catalogue].
The archive also contains [https://www.mun.ca/folklore/leach The MacEdward Leach Collection of Songs of Atlantic Canada].
== External links == * [https://www.mun.ca/folklore/munfla MUNFLA] * [https://www.mun.ca/folklore Department of Folklore, Memorial University of Newfoundland] * [https://www.mun.ca Memorial University of Newfoundland]

Further improvements to this outline are on the way ...--> [[File:Colouring pencils.jpg|thumb|Colour is an important aspect of many of the [[visual arts]].]] [[File:Edouard Manet - Luncheon on the Grass - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|''[[Le déjeuner sur l'herbe]]'' of [[Édouard Manet]].]] The following [[Outline (list)|outline]] is provided as an overview of and topical guide to the visual arts:
'''[[Visual arts]]''' – class of [[Art#Art forms|art forms]], including [[painting]], [[sculpture]], [[photography]], [[printmaking]] and others, that focus on the creation of works which are primarily [[visual]] in nature. Visual Arts that produce three-dimensional objects, such as [[sculpture]] and [[architecture]], are known as [[plastic arts]]. The current usage of ''visual arts'' includes [[fine arts]] as well as [[crafts]], but this was not always the case.
{{TOC limit|limit=2}}
==Types of visual art==
* [[Outline of architecture|Architecture]], process and product of planning, designing and construction. Architectural works, in the material form of buildings, are often perceived as cultural and political symbols and as works of art. * [[Outline of crafts|Arts and crafts]] * [[Asemic writing]] * [[Animation]] * [[Calligraphy]] * [[Cartoon]] * [[Ceramic art]] * [[Collage]] * [[Comics]] * [[Conceptual art]] * [[Decollage]] * [[Decorative art]] * [[Outline of design|Design]], as a verb, it refers to the process of originating and developing a plan for a new object (machine, building, product, etc.). As a noun, it is used both for the final plan or proposal (a drawing, model, or other description), or the result of implementing that plan or proposal (the object produced). ** [[Fashion design]] ** [[Garden design]] ** [[Graphic design]] ** [[Motion graphic design]] ** [[Web design]], creation and maintenance of [[website]]s * [[Outline of drawing|Drawing]] * [[Outline of film|Film]] * [[Found object]] * [[Graffiti]] * [[Illustration]] ** [[Concept art]] * [[Installation art]] * [[Land art]] * [[Mail art]] * [[Mixed media]] * [[Outline of painting|Painting]] * [[Outline of photography|Photography]] * [[Printmaking]] ** [[Etching]] ** [[Lithography]] ** [[Screen-printing]] * [[Rock balancing]] * [[Outline of sculpture|Sculpture]] * [[Street art]] * [[Typography]] * [[Video art]] * [[Internet art]]
== History of the visual arts== {{History of art sidebar}}
* [[History of animation]] * [[Arts and Crafts movement]] * [[Ceramic art#History|History of ceramic art]] * [[Comics#History|History of comics]] * [[Conceptual art#History|History of conceptual art]] * [[History of decorative arts]] * [[Drawing#History|History of drawing]] * [[History of fashion design]] * [[History of film]] * [[Graffiti#History|History of graffiti]] * [[Illustration#History|History of illustration]] * [[Installation art#History|History of installation art]] * [[Mixed media#History of mixed media]] * [[History of painting]] * [[History of photography]] * History of printmaking ** [[Etching#History|History of etching]] ** [[Lithography#The early process|History of lithography]] ** [[Screen-printing#History|History of screen-printing]] * [[History of sculpture]] * [[Video art#History of video art|History of video art]]
no location
== Elements of art == [[Elements of art]] – shape, form, value, line, color, space and texture * Shape – area defined by edges * Form – perceived volume or dimensionality * Value – use of lightness (tint, or white) and darkness (shade, or black) in a piece of art * [[Line (geometry)|Line]] – straight or [[curve]]d marks that span a distance between two points. For example, see [[line art]]. * [[Color]] – produced when light, striking an object, is reflected back to the eye. ** Properties of color *** [[Hue]] – red, yellow, blue, green, etc. *** [[Colorfulness|Intensity]] *** Value ([[Tints and shades|brightness]]) * Space – area that an artist provides for a particular purpose. Space includes the background, foreground and middle ground, and refers to the distances or area(s) around, between, and within things. * Texture – the way a three-dimensional work actually feels when touched, or the visual "feel" of a two-dimensional work
==General visual art concepts==

'''Phyllis Barnhart''' (December 16, 1922 – February 6, 2008) was an [[United States|American]] [[animator]] and [[Cel|cel painter]]. She was best known for her work on the 1982 animated [[film]], ''[[The Secret of NIMH]]'' (which was her only credit in an animated film, coincidentally enough).<ref name=bcf>{{cite news |title="NIMH" cel painter Phyllis Barnhart dead at 85 |url=http://forum.bcdb.com/forum/Error:%20Variable%20'hot_short_title'%20is%20not%20a%20code%20reference_P86048/ |work= [[Big Cartoon Forum]] |date=2008-02-20 |accessdate=2008-03-12}}</ref>
Barnhart was born on December 16, 1922, in [[Levan, Utah]].<ref name=bcf/> She began her career in animation at the [[Walt Disney Animation Studios|Disney]] during the 1940s, starting on the films ''[[Fun & Fancy Free]]'' and ''[[Melody Time]]'', at the inking and painting department.<ref name=bcf/> She later worked as a freelance assistant animator and cel painter for such classic animation studios as [[Filmation]], [[Hanna-Barbera]], [[Bandolier Films]], [[Chuck Jones|Chuck Jones Productions]], [[Murakami-Wolf-Swenson]], [[DePatie-Freleng]] and of course, [[Walt Disney Animation Studios|Disney]]. She worked as one of the lead cel painters for ''[[The Secret of NIMH]]'' (1982), which was created at [[Don Bluth Productions]].<ref name=bcf/>
Barnhart's husband [[Dale Barnhart]], died in 1996.<ref name=bcf/> He worked as a Disney [[Traditional animation#Layout|layout]] and [[background artist]] on films such as ''[[The Jungle Book]]'' and ''[[The Sword in the Stone (film)|The Sword in the Stone]]''.<ref name=bcf/>
Phyllis Barnhart died at the age of 85 on February 6, 2008, in [[Salt Lake City]], [[Utah]].<ref name=bcf/> She was survived by her daughter, Fotini, and three sons, Rhio, Roberleigh and [[Philo Barnhart]] (who worked as an assistant animator on films such as ''[[The Secret of NIMH]]'' and ''[[Beauty and the Beast (1991 film)|Beauty and the Beast]]'').<ref name=bcf/>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *{{IMDb name|id=1885999|name=Phyllis Barnhart}} *[http://www.cinematical.com/2008/02/18/rip-reel-important-people-february-18-2008/ Cinematical: RIP Reel Important People, Phyllis Barnhart]
